properties.field_incident_overview:
CURRENT STATUS 

The Sunrise Fire reached 100% containment 18 September, 2022 at 1130 local time.  No smoke is currently showing, crews will continue to patrol the fire area in the coming days.

CLOSURES AND SPECIAL MESSAGES 

The Sunrise Fire can be found at https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/8422/ 

There are no closures currently in place for this area although we ask that the public remain out of the area so that Fire Personnel can focus on the fire.
properties.title: Sunrise Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire in the Sonoran Desert
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Wildcat Fire was reported at approximately 9:20 a.m. Saturday morning near Vista Verde north of Dynamite Blvd and 136th Street, west of Bartlett Lake on the Cave Creek Ranger District. 

Due to favorable weather conditions and effective interagency suppression response, the wildfire is now smoldering within the existing perimeter and holding at 14,402 acres.

Bartlett Dam Road and Horseshoe Dam Road were reopened Thursday, May 23 at 4 p.m. Please stay alert and watch for firefighters and equipment in the area. 

Remember, drones and firefighting aircraft are a dangerous mix and could lead to accidents or slow down wildfire suppression operations. If you fly, we can’t.
properties.title: Wildcat Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Elk Fire, located on the Bighorn National Forest, was detected Friday, September 27, 2024 approximately 15 miles northwest of Dayton, Wyoming. Firefighters, airtankers and a helicopter initially responded to the fire. The fire was declared out on January 3, 2025.  Fire suppression repair and repair to impacted infrastructure along with monitoring for post-fire debris flows is ongoing.

National Forest Closures: There is a Trail Closure Order due to the Elk Fire that applies to portions of the Bighorn National Forest. Click on the following hyperlink for closure information and a map of the Elk Fire Closure.

Road Conditions: Please visit the Wyoming Department of Transportation for the latest road closure information. Please consider using other routes than Forest System Road 26 so that logging crews are able to complete their task of moving log decks.  

For easier use of this website while using a mobile phone, please click on the following hyper links for additional information of these topics.

Daily Updates

Daily Operations Update Videos

Maps

Photos

Videos

Closures

Announcements
properties.title: Elk Fire 2024

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire Complex
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Table Rock Complex is approximately 20 miles northwest or Greenville, South Carolina. The complex consists of the Table Rock Fire and the Persimmon Ridge Fire. The Table Rock Fire is located in Table Rock State Park and is currently active in South Carolina and North Carolina. The Persimmon Ridge Fire is located in Caesars Head State Park, it is active in South Carolina.

Table Rock Fire: 13,845 acres, 100% contained and controlled 

Persimmon Ridge Fire: 2,128 acres, 100% contained and controlled

Table Rock Complex Total: 15,973 acres, 100% contained and controlled
properties.title: 2025 - Table Rock Complex

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Pomas Fire was started by lightning in the Glacier Peak Wilderness and was first reported on the morning of June 13, 2025. Over the next several days firefighters conducted extensive air attack, dropping nearly 400,000 gallons of water on the fire. Because of extremely heavy fuel loads of dead and downed timber from the 2015 Wolverine Fire, aerial attack was ineffective in stopping the fire. Inaccessible by road, the fire is burning in very steep and rugged terrain. There are very limited opportunities for firefighters to work directly, safely, and effectively at the fire’s edge. 

Management of the Pomas Fire returned to the local unit on August 19th.

For most current closure orders please visit https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/okanogan-wenatchee/alerts. Closure orders are no longer being posted to Inciweb.
properties.title: Pomas Fire 2025

properties.field_incident_description: Firefighters are engaging in a full suppression strategy in steep and rocky terrain utilizing aircraft and existing dozer lines from the 2024 Shoe Fire. Control objectives are to keep the fire north of Pit River, southeast of Sulanharas Creek, and southwest of Fenders Ferry Road.
properties.field_incident_overview:
QUICK LINKS:  Daily Update          Daily Map         

Facebook: (New)Shasta-Trinity NF Fire and Aviation     Shasta Trinity National Forest

X.com @ShastaTrinityNF

Public Information: (530) 685-0536

2025.green@firenet.gov

www.fs.usda.gov/r05/shasta-trinity

GREEN FIRE August 17, 2025 Update:  The Green fire is at 19022 acres and 100% containment has been achieved. Resources continue suppression repair and backhaul of equipment and supplies no longer in use. Mopup and patrol of the Pit River Arm will continue as needed. 

Suppression repair continues on the 35N02 road and Curl Ridge. Fenders Ferry Road from Pitt 6 bridge to McCloud Campground will remain closed while crews complete the culvert work on the road.  The culverts are being repaired at Goose Gap near the east fork of Bills Creek.

FIRE ACTIVITY:  Minimal fire activity is expected.

FIRE WEATHER: Near to below normal temperatures are forecast across the Green Fire through Monday with rising relative humidity. There is a 20% chance of showers or thunderstorms on Saturday and Sunday, followed by  a gradual warming and drying trend.

EVACUATIONS: none

CLOSURES: Shasta-Trinity National Forest closure order for the Green Fire can be found at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/shasta-trinity/alerts/green-fire-closure-order.

INITIAL SITUATION: The Green Fire started following widespread thunderstorms and lightning on the afternoon and evening of June 30, 2025. The Shasta-Trinity National Forest saw more than 3,100 lightning strikes between June 30 and July 2, resulting in several wildfires. (Wildfire information for other current incidents on the Shasta-Trinity). Firefighters will continue monitoring the forest in the days ahead for holdover fires that may emerge from this week’s storms.

AIR QUALITY: Fire activity for the Green Fire is continuing to decrease.  Areas close to the fire could see brief periods of smoke, but no long duration impacts are expected.

NO DRONE ZONE: Drones pose a serious risk to firefighting and can cause air operations to cease. When drones interfere with firefighting efforts, a wildfire has the potential to grow larger and cause more damage.  For more information on drones the public can visit the FAA’s website at www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org “If you fly, we can’t!”
properties.title: Green Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
On July 6, a human-caused fire was reported in Olympic National Forest near the Mt. Rose Trailhead along the Lake Cushman Corridor. The fire – named the Bear Gulch Fire – is burning on a steep, rocky slope north of Lake Cushman in the Olympic National Forest and near the Staircase area of Olympic National Park. 

Management of the Bear Gulch and Tunnel Creek fires will transfer to local fire units on October 11, 2025.

Falling debris across NF 2400 (FS 24) continues to be a primary hazard in the area. Due to this significant safety concern, NF Road 2400 is closed, including access to day use, trailheads and other sites beyond the closure point, at mile marker 10.5. This junction is where the pavement ends and the Forest Service Road into the Staircase area of Olympic National Park begins. Access to Mount Rose Residential Division 2, 3 and 4 remains open.

Updates for this incident will be communicated as notable events occur. 

Evacuation Orders: All evacuations in the Lake Cushman area have been lifted. Current evacuation information: https://www.facebook.com/masoncosheriff


Lake Usage: Access to Lake Cushman is now open to public use.

For updates regarding the Bear Gulch Fire, you can also visit the Olympic National Forest website at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/olympic 
and follow www.facebook.com/beargulch2025/ on social media. Videos are available to those without Facebook accounts using that link.

Smoke Outlook: https://outlooks.airfire.org/outlook/e620ac47? 

Air Space Restrictions: There are no flight restrictions. The TFR was lifted 9/29/2025.

Fire Restrictions: Olympic National Park and Olympic National Forest have returned to standard campfire regulations on 10/07/25. Campers should use caution with any open flame and ensure fires are completely extinguished - cool to the touch - before leaving a site. Campers are required by law to stay with their campfire from start to finish.


Mason County lifted burn restrictions for recreational fires only Tuesday Sept. 30. Please note that while it is anticipated the restriction for Residential and Land Clearing burns will also be lifted soon, they remain in effect at this time. If you have any questions, feel free to contact the Fire Marshal at 360-427-9670, extension 309.

https://masoncountywa.gov/departments/community_development/fire_marshal/burn_restrictions.php
properties.title: Bear Gulch Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Lightning/Natural Caused Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
Background: The Dragon Bravo Fire began on July 4, 2025, from a lightning strike on the North Rim of Grand Canyon National Park. Firefighters and suppression resources responded quickly, constructing containment lines.

On the evening of July 11, strong northwest wind gusts—uncommon for the area—pushed the fire beyond containment features, resulting in significant growth. Limited nighttime visibility prevented aerial retardant and water drops; however, ground crews and air resources continued aggressive suppression efforts during the day, focusing on areas with the highest probability of success. The fire was being managed under a full suppression strategy. Hot temperatures, low relative humidity, and ongoing strong winds continued to drive very active fire behavior. Facilities in the North Rim developed area were impacted.

Crews are making strong progress on suppression repair, restoring disturbed land by dismantling dozer piles, stabilizing soil, and reestablishing vegetation. A top priority remains removing hazard trees along Highway 67 and main routes into the North Rim to ensure safety.

The fire was called 100% contained on Sept. 28, 2025. The North Rim of Grand Canyon National Park partially reopened to the public on Oct. 1, 2025.
properties.title: Dragon Bravo Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Two fires started south of Ovando, Montana on July 9th, 2025, and MTDNRC Clearwater resources responded to both. Ken Parks' Western Montana Type 3 All-Hazards Incident Management Team assumed command of both fires on July 10th, 2025, at 6pm. 

Green Mountain Fire 

Firefighters and aerial resources responded to a new fire start located 6 miles south of Ovando in the Green Mountain area on July 9th that was estimated at 10 acres burning in timber.

Garnet Fire

Firefighters and aerial resources responded to a new fire start located 12 miles southwest of Ovando on July 9th with aggressive fire behavior with spotting up to a quarter mile ahead of the fire.
properties.field_title_and_unit: MTMTS Green Mountain Fire Garnet Fire
properties.title: Green Mountain Fire & Garnet Fire
White Sage Fire

properties.field_incident_description: A regional lightning storm on July 10 started multiple incidents in the area including the Sowbelly fire.
properties.field_incident_overview: The Sowbelly Fire started on July 10, 2025 in the Dominguez Canyon Wilderness Area in Delta, Montrose, and Mesa counties. It grew to 2,274 acres and is now 95% contained. This will be the final update.
properties.title: Sowbelly Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The Big Bear Fire is a lightning-caused fire and is burning in steep, remote terrain in the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness.
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Big Bear Fire, a lightning-caused fire that started on July 9, is approximately 16,220 acres and 100% complete.  We are and will continue to assess conditions using remote sensing, lookouts, and flights for future point protection and staffing needs as necessary.

In addition, the Payette National Forest is actively coordinating with Nez Perce-Clearwater, Bitterroot, and Salmon-Challis National Forests to communicate with outfitters and other permit holders impacted by fire activity.  For the most up-to-date information on river conditions, please call the Salmon-Challis National Forest River Clerk Desk at 208-481-2625.  The phone line’s hours are 8 AM – 4 PM MST.

As a reminder, the status of the Big Bear Fire will be measured as percentage of completed incident objectives, which more accurately illustrates the amount of groundwork accomplished by firefighters for this and future updates.
properties.title: Big Bear

properties.field_incident_description: The Rush Fire is a lightning caused fire and is burning in steep, remote terrain in the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness.
properties.field_incident_overview: The status of the Rush Fire will be measured as percentage of completed incident objectives, which more accurately illustrates the amount of groundwork accomplished by firefighters. The Rush Fire, a lightning-caused fire that started on July 10, is approximately 7,908 acres and 100% completed.
properties.title: Rush

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Turner Gulch Fire was discovered on July 10, 2025, during a Red Flag event following a period of widespread dry lightning. Burning on both sides of Unaweep Canyon, these fires are challenging to access and threaten critical values near Gateway, Colorado, in Mesa County. Values at risk include human life, primary residences, and key infrastructure such as the powerline along Highway 141.

Initial attack operations were led by the Upper Colorado River Fire Management Unit (Type 3 Incident Management Team) on Bureau of Land Management (BLM) lands.  The Turner Gulch Fire expanded onto U.S. Forest Service land and private property. In response, the Mesa County Sheriff’s Department issued evacuation and pre-evacuation notices for areas along the Highway 141 corridor and the Uncompahgre Plateau.

On the evening of August 16, 2025, the Northern Rockies Incident Management Team 3 (NRIMT3) assumed command of the Turner Gulch Fire, following previous incident management teams. NRIMT3 has prioritized a full suppression strategy, with firefighter and public safety remaining the highest priority, and has made substantial progress on the incident. With the arrival of monsoonal moisture and greatly increased containment, management of the Turner Gulch Fire was turned over to a local Type 3 incident management team on August 27, 2025. On the morning of Wednesday September 3, 2025, the command of the Turner Gulch Fire transitioned from a Type 3 Organization to a local Type 4 organization. 

Evacuations: All evacuation orders have been lifted.   

Closures & Fire Restrictions: The Bureau of Land Management and the Grand Mesa, Uncompahgre and Gunnison (GMUG) National Forests announced emergency closures in and south of Unaweep Canyon. Additional details and a closure map are available at https://www.blm.gov/programs/public-safety-and-fire/fire-and-aviation/regional-information/colorado/upper-colorado-river-district or https://www.fs.usda.gov/r02/gmug/alerts.  

Fire restrictions are in place for all surrounding public lands and in Mesa County. More information can be found at https://westslopefireinfo.com/.  

Wildfires are a no-fly zone for unauthorized aircraft, including drones. If you fly, we can’t. For more information, visit http://knowbeforeyoufly.org. 

Operational Briefing videos can be watched on the Turner Gulch and Wright Draw YouTube page.
properties.title: Turner Gulch

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Deer Creek Fire ignited on the afternoon of July 10, 2025, near La Sal in San Juan County. Local, state, and federal firefighting resources immediately responded and continue to actively engage in suppression efforts. A Southeastern Utah Interagency Type 3 Incident Management Team is currently managing the fire and assumed command from the Nevada Type 3 Incident Management Team #2 on the evening of August 6, 2025.

The fire is now 100% contained as of August 11, 2025
properties.title: Deer Creek

properties.field_incident_overview:
This is the final update of the Type 3 team as they transfer command of the fire back to the local district as of tomorrow morning. 64 personnel remain assigned to the Billy Fire.

Unless there are significant changes in fire activity, this will be the last daily update of the Billy Fire.

-

The Billy Fire is a lightning-caused wildfire on the Tonto National Forest, 15 miles south of Young, Arizona. Firefighters are taking a full suppression strategy on the fire situated on the east side of the Sierra Ancha Mountains.
properties.title: Billy Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The fire was discovered at 7/13/2025, at approximately 2:22 PM. 
The fire is burning in timber near the communities of Richfield, Monroe, and Koosharem, Utah. 

Initial fire activity included extreme surface spread with tree torching and continuous potential for short to long-range crown runs with medium range spotting. The fire activity was described as extreme with measurable perimeter advancement and very high heat intensity development mainly due to the continued hot dry weather patterns. Increased moisture trends have allowed crews to initiate suppression repair activities.

Great Basin Team 3 Complex Incident Management Team assumed command of the incident at 6:00am on August 24, 2025.
properties.title: Monroe Canyon

properties.field_incident_overview:
As of Monday, July 28, this webpage will no longer be updated unless there is a significant increase in fire activity on the Wright Draw Fire. Please contact the BLM Grand Junction Field Office with any questions. Email: blm_co_gj_web_mail@blm.gov, Phone: 970-244-3000.

 A local type 3 incident management team will begin management of the Turner Gulch and Wright Draw Fires at 7 a.m., Monday, July 28. The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CIMT1) assumed management of the Turner Gulch and Wright Draw Fires on Tuesday morning, July 15, 2025. The Upper Colorado River Fire Management Unit Type 3 Incident Management Team previously managed the fire under extreme fire conditions.

The Turner Gulch and Wright Draw fires were both discovered on July 10th, 2025, during a red flag event that was preceded by extensive dry lightning. Burning on both sides of Unaweep Canyon, these fires are difficult to access and threatening values within the canyon and along Highway 141 near Gateway, Colorado. 

Extreme drought conditions, steep terrain, and hot and dry weather have been a challenge to firefighters on the Turner Gulch and Wright Draw Fires.

Evacuations:

Evacuations and pre-evacuations may occur if fire activity increases. For current evacuation information, please visit: https://www.facebook.com/Mesacountysheriffsoffice.

An interactive evacuation web map is available for checking the fire location and evacuation status. You can find it here. 

To sign up for Emergency Alerts, please visit the Grand Junction Regional Communication Center Emergency and Community Notification System website at https://bit.ly/Emergency_Alerts.

Closures and Fire Restrictions:

Highway 141 reopened on Monday, July 21. Increased traffic from members of the public wanting to look at the fire may impede fire operations and potentially put firefighters at risk or prevent them from moving quickly in response to increased fire activity. Please be alert and drive carefully.

For information on area, road, trail, and recreation site closures visit: https://www.facebook.com/BLMColorado

or https://www.blm.gov/office/grand-junction-field-office.

Fire restrictions may be found at this link: https://www.mesacounty.us/departments-and-services/sheriff/divisions/emergency-services/fire-restrictions.

Wildfires are a no-fly zone for unauthorized aircraft, including drones. If you fly, we can’t. For more information, visit http://knowbeforeyoufly.org.

Operational Briefing videos can be watched on the Turner Gulch and Wright Draw YouTube page. 

The Community meeting held in Gateway on Wednesday, July 16 can be viewed at this link.
properties.title: Wright Draw

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Sucker Creek Fire was reported at approximately 1 p.m. on July 27, two miles north of Lincoln, Montana. The fire is burning in grass and timber.

Crew have secured control lines and are continuing mop up operations up to two chains (132 feet) from the fire perimeter. Over the next two days, remaining personnel will continue to search for potential spot fires driven by recent winds, reinforce dozer and hand line, and cool remaining hot spots with water from hose lays. 

There are no evacuations in place at this time. Sucker Creek Road is closed due to fire suppression operations. Please avoid the area to ensure public and firefighter safety.
properties.title: Sucker Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_description: A lightning strike ignited the Mudd Fire July 31,2025 during the late morning hours. Bureau of Land Mangement (BLM) as well as other resources are now staffing the fire. The Mudd fire currently is 4 acres in size. Air suppression resources have been utilizing the Paonia Reservoir for a water dip site to strategically use for fire suppression. Current weather conditions have cloudy conditions and t-storms in the area. The Mudd fire is burning in mixed brush. Resources will remain staffing the fire overnight.
properties.field_incident_overview:
Muddy Fire Update 8/4/2025 FINAL:

Weekend Summary:

Over the weekend fire crews successfully established containment of 100% around the fire perimeter of the Muddy Fire. Fire crews also achieved 100% control of the Muddy fire with active mop up operations. The Muddy fire has now been placed in monitor status by the local BLM Southwest District Fire Unit.  This will be the final update for the Muddy fire.

 

Muddy Fire Update 8/2/2025

8/1/2025 shift summary:

All fire resources continue to construct fire line around the entire perimeter of the Muddy Fire. The Multi Mission Aircraft (DFPC MMA) flew over the fire utilizing the infrared heat detection capability. The infrared heat scan is a great tool that is used to detect any heat source within the fire perimeter. The infrared image that is generated is transferred to a map and sent to the ground fire resources to help them seek and destroy any heat threats. A photo of the infrared can be viewed in the photos section on this site.

Fire crews have also begun the early stages of mop up on the Muddy Fire. At this stage, crews will continuously work deeper interior from the fires edge digging out ash pits, digging/grubbing up hot roots and smoldering duff that could cause issues if not addressed. Fire crews continue to staff the fire overnight. Adverse weather conditions continue to be an issue for the fire crews working the Muddy fire due to t-storms and lightning in the area.

 

8/2/2025

All fire lines held overnight on the Muddy Fire. Crews remained in place through the night and are back in action for the day shift. Overall plan for the weekend will be finalizing containment around the fires edge on the Muddy Fire. Crews will continue mop up operations, working the fire line edge, securing, patrolling and working deeper interior. Fire behavior has significantly decreased to smoldering and creeping. Fire crews could face another day of challenging fire weather conditions with possible afternoon t-storms and higher winds. Overall, crews continue to produce good safe work.

The next update for the Muddy Fire will be Monday 8/4/2025, unless any significant events happen.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

Muddy Fire Update 8/1/2025

Summary:

Muddy Fire Update:

* 30% Containment

* Revised fire perimeter to 3 acres.

*All fire lines held overnight.

*Fire crews will continue the construction of fire line and engage in mop up operations.

Previous day recap: Fire crews responded to a new start located 2 miles East of the Paonia Reservoir late morning. The initial fire was reported from a reconnaissance fire detection aircraft by the MMA (Multi Mission Aircraft). The MMA spotted a heat signature and reported the new start to the Montrose Interagency Fire Dispatch Center. The initial size up was .1 size, cause was lightning from the previous day, fire burning in grass, brush and timber. The new start was plotted on BLM land.

A few hours later, gaining access to the fire, fire resources estimated the fire to be approximately 5 acres and named the incident the Muddy fire. Private property was within the proximity of the fire parameter and fire air resources were ordered to assist. Through the heat of the day ground and air resources made good progress with cooling off the fire and constructing fire line. 

By the evening weather conditions started to deteriorate with t-storms and rain moving into the fire area. Aviation resources (due to the weather conditions) had to disengage from the fire, as well as ground fire crews due to lightning exposure. Rain did reach the fire area and crews eventually reengaged the fire. Crews staffed the fire overnight with no flareups to the fire line.

Plans for today 8/1/2025

Crews will continue to construct fire line around the fire perimeter, mainly chainsaw (saw) and cold trialing the fires edge. Mop up operations will begin to secure all fire line within a certain depth which will prevent any future threats. Fire crews will look to have the Muddy fire fully contained by the end of shift on 8/1/2025.

 

Muddy Fire Update:

*Fire perimeter resized to 4 acres.

*Fire crews have been actively engaged with fire line construction. Good progress has been made.

*Incoming weather has disengaged fire suppression aircraft

*The Muddy fire is currently receiving light rain.

 

All ground crews will remain on scene of the Muddy fire overnight. Current fire behavior has decreased due to suppression activities and weather conditions.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Active Wildfire Alert!

Fire name: Muddy Fire

Location: 2 Miles East of Paonia Reservoir, Gunnison County, off Hwy 133 located on BLM land.

Size: Currently 5 acres

Cause: Lightning

Fuels burning: Oak Brush

Current Status: Active fire behavior, fire resources currently on scene and engaged with fire. Aircraft resources inbound.
properties.title: Muddy Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
MAPS: Public Information Map  

AIR QUALITY:  AirNow.gov    |    SLOCleanAir.org

 

SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENTS: California Interagency Incident Management Team 8 is preparing to transfer the incident to a local type 3 Team on Sunday, August 31, 2025. For information please follow the Los Padres National Forest Facebook page, or the Los Padres National Forest official website.

The public information phone line for the Gifford Fire, has been handed back to the Los Padres National Forest, please call 805-9259538.  

 

COMMUNITY MEETING: Recording of community meeting that occurred August 29,2025.

 

INITIAL SITUATION:  Los Padres National Forest firefighters responded to reports of multiple wildfires along Highway 166, west of Cuyama, in the afternoon of Friday, August 1st, 2025. Evacuations are in progress and road closures are now in effect. Los Padres National Forest is currently in unified command with Santa Barbara County Fire. A complex Incident Management Team has been ordered and will in-brief on the evening of Saturday, August 2nd, 2025.

 

FOREST AREA CLOSURE: Portions of the Los Padres National Forest are temporarily closed for public safety and the protection of natural resources from August 29, 2025 to Feb 28, 2026. The closure will include the entire Santa Lucia Ranger District and a portion of the Mount Pinos Ranger District. 

 

KNOW WHERE YOU CAN FLY: Drones pose a serious risk to firefighting and can cause air operations to cease. When drones interfere with firefighting efforts, a wildfire has the potential to grow larger and cause more damage. A FAA Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect and any private aircraft or drone that violates the TFR could face serious criminal charges. For more information on drones the public can visit the FAA’s website at www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org “If you fly, we can’t!”
properties.title: Gifford Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
As of Monday, August 11, the Kirkland Fire is 100% contained at 913 acres. 

Remaining resources continue to patrol and monitor the fire's edge checking for visible heat within the interior. 

The Kirkland Fire started Friday, August 1, approximately 3:15 pm, 2 miles northeast of Hillside in Yavapai County. Due to hot and dry conditions, and driven by the wind, the fire quickly grew, pushing to the north/northeast toward the community of Yava. 

Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management on Facebook:https://www.facebook.com/arizonaforestry

Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management on X: https://x.com/azstateforestry

Ready Set Go: https://ein.az.gov/ready-set-go

Yavapai County Emergency Alerts Registration: https://www.ycsoaz.gov/I-Want-To/Services/Sign-up-for-Emergency-Notifications.
properties.title: Kirkland Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Rosa Fire Last Update          Final Rosa Fire Map         

The fire remains within the existing perimeter, no growth is expected. Fire Suppression repair has been completed.  

Management of the fire has been turned back to the local units (Riverside County Fire, and the San Bernardino National Forest.

Closures:  

Pinyon Campground, Santa Rosa Truck Trail and associated remote "yellow post" campsites, Cahuilla Tewanet Viewpoint, and the Sawmill and Cactus Springs Trail have reopened for public use.   

The Upper Palm Canyon Trail will remain closed and a long-term closure order will be issued which will assist the fire area to begin the recovery process.

Information for Residents:

Sign up for local emergency alerts at: RivCoReady.org/AlertRivCo and download the Genasys Protect app

Protect your property:  Learn about Defensible Space at https://www.fire.ca.gov/dspace 

For additional information when returning home after a wildfire, refer to: www.readyforwildfire.org 

Incident Camera Link: https://cameras.alertcalifornia.org/?pos=33.7403_-116.4633_9&id=Axis-ToroPeak1 

Air Quality:  For Up-to-date information on air quality in your area, please visit https://fire.airnow.gov/ For links to information and tips on managing wildfire smoke exposure, please visit:  https://californiasmokeinfo.blogspot.com/ 

Evacuation Orders:  

All residential evacuation orders arehave been rescinded.  

Power Pole Replacement continues in the Fire effected area.  click https://www.anzaelectric.org/rosa-fire to read a message about ongoing efforts to re-energize the area.
properties.title: Rosa Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: San Bernardino National Forest firefighters responded to reports of a wildfire one mile NE of Holcomb Valley Campground in Big Bear, in the morning of Monday, August 4th, 2025. Holcomb Valley Campground was evacuated and remains closed.  Local Forest road closures are now in effect. 

 

CURRENT SITUATION: 

The ending size of the Gold Fire is 1036 acres due to more accurate mapping of the fire perimeter. Today the San Bernardino National Forest Type 3 Team is taking over the fire.  Mop-up, suppression repair, mitigating hazard trees and putting out the few places with a little smoke in the interior of the fire area are the main tasks in cleaning up this fire.  An excavator will also be working to move rocks back in place along the John Bull Trail that were moved for firefighter entry.  It will also be used to deck the logs of cut hazard trees.

Note that this is the final current situation update unless significant activity occurs.


FOREST VISITORS: A Temporary Forest Closure Order 05-12-52-25-03 has been implemented. Holcomb Valley Campground, John Bull Trail, and Holcomb Valley, are being impacted by the Gold Fire. Snags (dead standing trees), and widow-makers (broken limbs suspended in tree branches) ash pits (large holes filled with hot ash and embers from incinerated trees and shrubs), equipment and fire personnel are some of the many safety risks to the public. For your safety and the safety of our firefighters please honor the Forest Order and stay clear of the closed area.

This order is a temporary order and will remain in place until September 7, 2025. The San Bernardino National Forest has 900 miles of Off Road trails for your enjoyment during the closure.

The full closure order and map can be viewed here: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/sanbernardino/alerts/gold-fire-area-closure

 

AREA CLOSURES: The following recreation sites and Forest Service roads are temporarily closed for fire personnel and public safety.

Recreation Sites: 

  • Holcomb Valley Campground
  • Tanglewood Group Campground
  • Pinnacles Climbing Area 

Forest Service Roads: 

  • 3N10 and all spur roads,
  • 3N07 and all spur roads,
  • 3N32
  • 3N43
  • 3N09
  • 3N02
  • 3N05
  • 3N23
  • 3N26
  • 3N54
  • 3N61
  • 3N76
  • 3N79
  • 3N82
  • 3N83

 

KNOW WHERE YOU CAN FLY: Drones pose a serious risk to firefighting and can cause air operations to cease. When drones interfere with firefighting efforts, a wildfire has the potential to grow larger and cause more damage. A FAA Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect and any private aircraft or drone that violates the TFR could face serious criminal charges. For more information on drones the public can visit the FAA’s website at www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org “If you fly, we can’t!”
properties.title: 2025 BDF Gold Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Elk fire was discovered on Saturday, August 2nd as a lightning strike on private land in the Oak Ridge area. Drought with severe and extreme weather conditions along with two days of red flag warning caused heightened fire activity. Residences were evacuated from the area. As weather conditions changed and remained favorable for the Elk Fire, crews were able to gain substantial line around the Elk Fire. 

The Elk Fire is currently reported as being 100% contained.

For latest on evacuation notices and to sign up for reverse 911

Rio Blanco County: https://rioblancoalerts.genasys.com/portal/en
properties.title: Elk RBX Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Stoner Mesa Fire has been burning along Stoner Creek and on Taylor Mesa. Fire behavior had been extreme early in the incident due to the prolonged lack of moisture, low humidity levels, strong shifting winds and lots of available fuel. Heavy rainfall in late August and into September has significantly reduced fire activity. Fire activity is now minimal, with only isolated pockets of heat. Crews are now focused on repairing firelines and roads in the fire area and removing equipment no longer needed.  

The Stoner Mesa Fire area closure has been rescinded. Dangerous conditions may persist from fire-weakened trees and dangerous conditions during heavy rain.
properties.title: Stoner Mesa Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Lee and Grease fires were discovered on August 2nd as lightning strikes on Bureau of Land Management managed land in the Piceance Creek area. The Lee and Grease fires quickly met to be known exclusively as the Lee fire. Drought with severe and extreme weather conditions along with multiple days of red flag warnings and heightened fire activity, the Lee fire grew over 100,000 acres in eight days. Firefighters have been working to find areas of opportunity in the southern area of the fire to reduce spread. 

For latest on evacuation notices and to sign up for reverse 911 for your county follow - 

Lee and Elk Fire Evacuation Zones Map (Rio Blanco and Garfield Counties) - https://bit.ly/lee-fire-zones

Rio Blanco County: https://rioblancoalerts.genasys.com/portal/en 

Garfield County Register for Alerts: https://garco911.com/emergency-notification-system/ 

Garfield County Incident Updates and Subscribe to emails: https://www.garfieldcounty.net/
properties.title: Lee Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The Bronco Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
properties.field_incident_overview: The Bronco Fire is footprint is on the San Carlos Apache Agency, located 30 miles northeast of San Carlos, Arizona. The lightning-caused fire was reported on on August 3, 2025 burning in timber, chaparral, and brush.
properties.title: Bronco Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Over the next few days, the Northern Utah Team will focus on repair activities, continue to increase completion, and work towards opening closure areas as soon as it is safe to do so. 

Fire suppression repair activities include repairing control lines created by heavy equipment and handcrews. Specifically, crews rehabilitate these control lines into a more natural state by replacing soil and overlaying the area with brush and other forest debris. Waterbars are constructed to direct water off of fire lines to prevent erosion. These efforts are vital to restoring the ecosystem its natural state and providing proper stewardship of our forest.

Summit County Sheriff’s Office has updated evacuation notices. Hinckley Boy Scout Camp has been downgraded from GO to SET. Christmas Meadows has been downgraded from SET to READY. Manorlands and Uintalands remain in READY status.
properties.title: Beulah Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The Indian Fire is a full suppression wildfire.
properties.field_incident_overview: The Indian Creek Fire started August 5, 2025, on the Fort Apache Indian Reservation. It was burning in grass, brush, Juniper and Ponderosa Pine in steep and rugged terrain that was challenging for firefighters to access.
properties.title: Indian Creek

properties.field_incident_description: The Mountain incident is located near the area of the Mammoth fire which burned in July.  U.S. Forest Service-Modoc National Forest  Fire resources, including engines, crews, and fire suppression aircraft, are responding to a new fire incident visible from HWY 139 near Casuse Mountain with more resources on order. The Mountain Fire is approximately 250 acres burning in grass and brush with a moderate rate of spread.
properties.field_incident_overview:
🔥8/12 Mountain Fire update 3:30 PM  🔥

The Mountain Fire is currently 30% contained at 980 acres, with no significant growth reported. The aerial support during this incident has been crucial, aiding in the fire line construction for the firefighters working on the ground. 

Today, crews are continuing mop-up operations, focusing on full suppression and containment of the fire. 

**Fire Weather:** Isolated critical conditions are expected today and Wednesday due to gusty winds and low relative humidity (RH). Dry conditions are expected to persist throughout the week, with temperatures gradually returning to near seasonal norms. A dry front is predicted to move through the region today and continue into Wednesday, which may bring increased wind speeds. These winds, coupled with low daytime RH, could create isolated areas of critical fire weather conditions. 

The public is urged to stay clear of areas where firefighters are actively working and to help prevent new fires from starting.
properties.title: Mountain Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
INITIAL SITUATION: A brush fire was reported at 1:00 am in the morning east of interstate 5 and north of Smokey Bear Rd. In the early hours of the fire, firefighters experienced dangerous rates of spread and the fire quickly grew to over 100 acres. The fire has continued to burn south towards Vista Del Lago. Two unoccupied RV's were destroyed at the Pyramid Lake RV park early on in the incident. The fire has attempted to cross Interstate 5 three times.

 

CURRENT CONDITION: The King fire is 100% contained. All road closures have been lifted.

 

KNOW WHERE YOU CAN FLY: Drones pose a serious risk to firefighting and can cause air operations to cease. When drones interfere with firefighting efforts, a wildfire has the potential to grow larger and cause more damage. A FAA Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) is in effect and any private aircraft or drone that violates the TFR could face serious criminal charges. For more information on drones the public can visit the FAA’s website at www.KnowBeforeYouFly.org “If you fly, we can’t!”
properties.title: King Fire

properties.field_incident_description:
The Horn fire is located on private property and DNRC-managed land between Cliff Lake and Highway 87 in Madison County, near the Montana-Idaho border. Fuels in the area are primarily grass and brushy fuels.

Horn Creek Road, Cliff Lake Road, and Wade Lake Road are open as of 8/18. Wade Lake and Cliff Lake are also open to the public.
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Horn Fire was reported around 2:30 pm on Wednesday, August 13th. The cause of fire was lightning. 

As of Monday 8/25, the Horn Fire is 2,800 acres and 100% contained. Crews should be finishing rehab today and then demobilizing. 

Firefighters ask that everyone use caution when recreating to avoid causing additional fires. Secure chains when towing and check MTFireInfo.org for fire restrictions. Beaverhead and Madison County are in Stage 1 restrictions, meaning campfires are not allowed unless in a developed campground with an established ring. Always fully extinguish your campfire until it is cold to the touch.
properties.title: Horn Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
This page is covering the Washington Fire and the nearby Sheep Spring Fire.

The lightning caused Washington Fire was discovered on Wednesday, August 13, 2025. Firefighters are working to fully suppress the fire, with the top priority being the safety of both the public and firefighters.

On Friday, August 15, 2025 at 0600, the management of the Washington Fire transitioned to Southwest Incident Management Team 1, led by Incident Commander, Carl Schwope. 

On August 19, 2025 the team assisted with the response to a new lightning caused fire on the Tonto. That became the Sheep Spring FIre and was transitioned to Southwest Incident Management Team 1 on August 20, 2025.

Both fires were transitioned to local Type 3 teams on August 23 at 0600. 

Sheep Spring Fire transitioned back to the local unit (Type 5) and was placed in monitor and patrol status as of August 25 at 4 p.m.

To sign up for evacuation notices in Gila County, visit: https://gilacountyaz.genasys.com/portal/en

To sign up for evacuation notices in Coconino County, visit: https://www.coconino.az.gov/2612/Emergency-Notification-System
properties.title: Washington Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 will transfer command to the local unit at 6 pm on 08/27/2025. A Type 4 organization will assume command of the fire.  This will be the final update for the Red Canyon Fire unless fire conditions change.

Any future inquiries for the Red Canyon Fire, please contact: 

BLM, Worland Field Office 

307-347-5100 

https://www.blm.gov/office/worland-field-office 

Hot Springs Co. Emergency Management &  Sheriff’s Department 

307-864-4649 or 307-864-2622 

https://www.hscounty.com/departments/emergency-management 

For information regarding hunting in the area, please contact Wyoming Game and Fish Cody Regional Office: 307-527-7125. 

The lightning caused Red Canyon fire was reported on Wednesday, August 14th east of Thermopolis, WY in Hot Springs County.  The fire is burning on a combination of BLM, state, and private lands.  Extreme weather conditions in light dry fuels heightened fire activity and the Red Canyon Fire grew to over 100,000 acres in 4 days.    

The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 assumed command of the fire on Monday August 18th with full-suppression efforts and public and firefighter safety the highest priorities. 

Containment continued to increase thanks to the hard work of firefighters.  Crews continue to patrol the perimeter of the fire and the majority of suppression repair efforts have been completed. 

The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 would like to sincerely thank our partners, cooperators, and residents for welcoming the team and supporting suppression efforts. Together, we accomplished the mission while maintaining both public and firefighter safety.
properties.title: Red Canyon Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Cloudrest Fire was reported on August 14, 2025, around 3:44 p.m., from the Alert West camera system. It is located approximately 15 miles north of Virginia City, MT. The fire is burning in thick subalpine fir timber with a heavy dead and downed fuel component. The cause of the fire was determined to be from a thunderstorm. The fire is burning at 8,000 feet in elevation.

On August 30, 2025, at 6 PM, Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8 took over command of the Fire from Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 6. September 8, 2025, at 7AM, NWCIMT transferred command of the fire to a local Type 3 Incident Management Team. The Type 3 Incident Management Team transferred command back to the local Ranger District fire staff on September 17, 2025.
properties.title: Cloudrest

properties.field_incident_overview:
INCIDENT SUMMARY

Lightning ignited the Windy Rock Fire at approximately 1700 on August 14, 2025, in the Hoodoo Mountain Wilderness Study Area, north of Gold Creek and Phosphate in Powell County, Montana. The fire was first reported at 100 acres, but grew quickly in steep, heavily timbered terrain with significant dead and down trees.

This fire is jointly managed under a full suppression strategy between the Bureau of Land Management and the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation. 

The last daily update was provided October 2, 2025.

As of October 5, 2025, a Type 4 Incident Commander from the DNRC Anaconda Unit will coordinate ongoing suppression repair activities. Firefighter personnel and equipment will be active in the area through the fall. Expect to see smoke, as the fire will continue to burn within the perimeter of established control lines until the area receives significant, repeated precipitation.  

A BLM Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team will be working in the area in fall 2025 to assess post-fire effects and produce a plan outlining actions necessary to mitigate damage resulting from the fire. The goal of the BAER Team will be to establish cost effective post-fire stabilization measures necessary to protect human life, property, and critical natural and cultural resources from further damage and to start the process of recovery.

A closure order for BLM-managed lands in the fire area remains in effect for public lands impacted by the fire and suppression repair activities. Road closures remain in place for portions of Brock Creek, Braziel Creek, Warm Spring Creek, and Carten Creek roads. 

For up to date information on the closure, visit facebook.com/BLMMontana or the Missoula Field Office website: blm.gov/office/missoula-field-office
properties.title: Windy Rock Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Sleeper Ranch fire experienced extreme fire behavior and rapid growth during the Initial Attack. Aircraft continue to work the fire today as additional ground resources work their way to the fire.  

A Type 3 Incident Management Team has been ordered and is enroute.
properties.title: Sleeper Ranch Fire

properties.field_incident_description:
The McAllister Fire is located on private, state, and BLM land 3 miles south or Norris, and 3 miles north of Ennis Lake, on either side of HWY 287. The fire is burning mainly grass and scattered patches of trees.
There is an evacuation warning for residents in the area between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West, and US Highway 287.
properties.field_incident_overview:
The McAllister Fire was reported around 5:15pm, Saturday August 16th. The cause of the fire was lightning. 

As of Wednesday, 8/27, the fire is estimated at 3,560 acres with 95% containment. 

Crews are working around the perimeter patrolling the line. 

Resources will continue operations with the objective to creating a cold, secure buffer around the entire perimeter working for about the next week.

The evacuation warning has been lifted as of 8/20/25 for the areas between Bradley Creek, Shining Mountains West and US Highway 287 (between mile markers 61 and 64). There are no current road closures in place.

With moisture coming the next few days, crews will be patrolling and doing suppression repair.
properties.title: McAllister Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Incident is located 6 miles east of Paradise
properties.field_incident_overview: The Knowles Fire was reported on August 17, 2025. It is located along the Flathead River near the Full Curl Wildlife Management Area. The fire is being jointly managed under a full suppression strategy by the Montana Department of Natural Resources & Conservation (DNRC) and the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes (CSKT).
properties.title: Knowles Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The fire is burning in rugged terrain with heavy dead and down timber. Firefighters will continue to utilize both direct and indirect tactics to guide fire behavior toward natural barriers such as treeline scree fields and minimize threats to private property, communities, infrastructure, watersheds, and other critical assets. Access is difficult, as much of the fire is in a non-motorized wilderness area.
properties.field_incident_overview: The La Plata Fire was reported on August 17, 2025, at 5:46 p.m. The wildfire is located on the Pike-San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Camanche Grasslands on the south side of Twin Lakes Reservoir approximately 4 miles southwest of Twin Lakes, Colorado.
properties.title: La Plata

properties.field_incident_description: The fire is burning in rugged terrain with heavy dead and down timber. Firefighters will continue to utilize both direct and indirect tactics to guide fire behavior toward natural barriers such as treeline scree fields and minimize threats to private property, communities, infrastructure, watersheds, and other critical assets. Access is difficult, as much of the fire is in a non-motorized wilderness area.
properties.field_incident_overview: The La Plata Fire was reported on August 17, 2025, at 5:46 p.m. The wildfire is located on the Pike-San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Camanche Grasslands on the south side of Twin Lakes Reservoir approximately 4 miles southwest of Twin Lakes, Colorado.
properties.title: La Plata

properties.field_incident_overview:
A Type 5 incident management organization has taken command of the Derby fire, with Kris Hills as Incident Commander. 

The Derby Fire was ignited by lightning on an extremely steep cliff face in a remote area near the Flat Tops Wilderness on Saturday evening, August 16, 2025. Initial attack efforts by smokejumpers on Sunday were hindered by rollout of burning material, repeatedly igniting the slope below the main fire. 

Protection of life and property are key objectives for managing this fire.
properties.title: Derby Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
The West Fork Fire Started on 8/19/2025, located 23 miles northwest of West Yellowstone, Montana, in the South Madison's just North of the Beaver Creek FS cabin, Hebgen Ranger District, Custer Gallatin National Forest.

The West Fork Fire has shown no growth since September 1, staying within established containment lines and maintaining its existing footprint. Recent and upcoming weather systems help keep the risk of new fire activity low, enabling crews to concentrate on extinguishing any smoldering pockets, suppression repair, and addressing heavy fuels within the fire perimeter. Minimal smoke may still be visible from interior pockets, but it is not expected to affect containment. Crews will continue monitoring hot spots until the fire is completely extinguished. 

The West Fork Burned Area Emergency Response (BAER) Team completed its assessment on September 26. The team's specialists conducted field assessments and modeling to identify threats to public safety, property, and natural or cultural resources caused by the fire. Based on their findings, the team has developed a plan to help stabilize the area, reduce immediate post-fire dangers, and support long-term restoration of the landscape.

The closure order for the West Fork Fire Forest Service Trail 200 (Order 01-11-07-25-04) has been rescinded, and it is now open for public access. However, please be aware that this trail is located in a burned area and could present numerous hazards, including falling trees and snags, rolling rocks, and logs. Isolated pockets of fire may still be active within the fire's perimeter. Recreationists are advised to exercise extreme caution.
properties.title: West Fork Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Dollar Lake Fire is burning in the Green River Lakes area of the Bridger-Teton National Forest's Pinedale Ranger District. The fire was reported at 2:16 p.m. on Thursday, August 21.

Dollar Lake is located along a 25-mile dirt and gravel road that follows the Green River through the national forest. The road is a popular camping and recreation site. In a matter of hours on Aug. 21, the wind-driven fire grew from 20 acres to 600 acres in size. The fast-moving fire prompted the Sublette County Sheriff's office to immediately issue a road closure and evacuation of the area.

The cause of the fire has not been determined.
properties.title: Dollar Lake Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: The Willow Creek Fire was reported on Friday, August 22 on the Greys River District of the Bridger-Teton National Forest, burning in timber southwest of the town of Smoot. This is a full suppression fire.
properties.title: Willow Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
At approximately 3:00 p.m. Friday, August 22, 2025, the Little Fire started along the north side of SR-178, 5 miles west of Borel Road. Multiple agencies responded including U.S. Forest Service, Kern County Fire Department, Bureau of Land Management, Kern County Sheriff's Office, California Highway Patrol, and Caltrans. The terrain is steep and rocky, with extremely dry vegetation. The cause of this fire is under investigation. 

Forest Closure:  The Little Fire area has been closed by the Sequoia National Forest until September 28 2025.  Please check the Forest webpage for the details and the map:

 National Forest - Little Fire Closure Order

As of 8/29/2025 8:30 p.m., from the Kern County Sheriff's Office:

 

Haga clic aqui para Espanol: https://ahas1.com?es7774


: https://ahas1.com?7774

Little Fire - Evacuation Warning LIFTED Update #5

This is an update the Little Fire in the Southwest of Lake Isabella area. The Evacuation Warning for KRN 709-B in Southwest of Lake Isabella has been LIFTED. There are no further advisories in place at this time. 

Genasys Protect zone(s):KRN709-B

Follow the link to view a map of the area that was under the Evacuation Warning. https://go.genasys.com/x2knl9

If you have an emergency, call 911.
properties.title: Little Fire 2025

properties.field_incident_description: Lightning Fire
properties.field_incident_overview:
Start Date: August 24, 2025 

Cause: Lightning 

Location: Sierra National Forest, Fresno County 

Acres Burned: 59,844 

Containment: 99% 

Personnel: 248

Hand Crews: 1

Dozers: 2

Engines: 2

Water Tenders: 1


10/18/25 FINAL UPDATE: 
This is the final update for the Garnet Fire unless significant activity occurs. Tulare County Type 3 IMT transferred command of the fire to the Sierra National Forest Type 3 IMT on 10/17/25 at 6:00 P.M.

Current Situation: 
Fire behavior remains minimal and has further decreased in activity from recent rain and snow fall. Firefighters will continue to patrol and assess hazard trees, snags and clogged culverts.

Safety: 
Motorists should be aware of large machinery moving to and from the fire perimeter on area roads, adding to congestion and potential intermittent closures at choke points and mid-slope grades.

Air Quality: 
Check local air quality at: airnow.gov/.

Forest Closure: 
The Sierra National Forest issued a reduced Forest Closure Order on October 6, 2025. This reduced closure order was coordinated with the Fresno County Sheriff’s Office, along with multiple local, state, and federal agency cooperators, to identify the minimum area necessary for the safety of firefighting resources and forest visitors. An FS-7700 form will be required to enter the closed portion of the forest. Contact the District Ranger’s Office at (559) 855-5355 to request the FS-7700 form. For a copy of the closure and map, please visit the Sierra National Forest website at: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/sierra/alerts/garnet-fire-closure-update-oct-6.
properties.title: Garnet Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
QUICK LINKS

Daily Update

Daily Maps

Daily Operations Update (Video)

Facebook:  Emigrant Fire    

Smoke: https://www.airnow.gov

Public information: https://linktr.ee/2025.emigrantfire 

SPECIAL NOTE: The Middle Fork Type 3 Team transferred command to a local Type 4 Incident Commander on Tuesday, Oct 7, 2025 at 8 a.m. 

BACKGROUND: The lightning-caused Emigrant Fire was reported on Aug. 24, 2025. The fire ignited in a remote area 3 miles southwest of Indigo Springs Campground. The fire spread rapidly through the 2009 Tumblebug Fire burn scar, which has many standing and fallen dead trees plus dense brush, and few opportunities for direct control of the fire.  Indirect control lines were established around the fire, many along roads or in locations previously used by the Tumblebug Fire. The fire reached some containment lines, but growth of the fire largely stopped due to a combination of recent rainfall and suppression activities.

RESTRICTIONS & CLOSURES:  

Information on the Willamette National Forest Emergency Fire Closure can be found by clicking on the highlighted link.

SMOKE: Smoke and air quality information is available at https://www.oregonsmoke.org/ and https://www.airnow.gov.

DRONES AND AVIATION SAFETY:  Wildfires are a no-fly zone for unauthorized aircraft, including drones. If you fly, we can’t.  For more information, visit http://knowbeforeyoufly.org.  Facebook video of Air Operations and TFR's

ABOUT THE FOREST:  The Willamette National Forest is 1,675,407 acres in size. The varied landscape of high mountains, narrow canyons, cascading streams, and wooded slopes offer excellent opportunities for visitors and make the Forest valuable for many purposes.

The Willamette National Forest is easily accessed from the Willamette Valley cities of Salem, Albany, and Eugene. Four important highways-U.S. Route 20 and Oregon State Routes 22, 58, and 126-cross the Forest. Two National Scenic Byways, McKenzie Pass – Santiam Pass National Scenic Byway and the West Cascades National Scenic Byway take visitors on a tour of tall forests and sparkling water. Over 6,000 miles of road on the Forest offer a chance to get off the beaten path.
properties.title: Emigrant Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Ransome Fire was detected on August 21, 2025 and from a previous lightning storm. It is burning in the Quartz Creek drainage 11 miles northwest of Libby, MT in the 2017 West Fork Fire scar.  

*Updates will now only occur with any significant changes.
properties.title: Ransome Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Dillon Fire was detected August 25, 2025 in the area of Dillon Creek just west of the Klamath River about 16 miles north of Orleans, California. The fire quickly grew to more than 300 acres by evening with extreme fire behavior and long-range spotting. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CA-CIMT 1) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on August 29. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 6 (CA-CIMT 6) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on September 11. 

North Coast Interagency Incident Management Team Type 3 assumed command of the Dillon Fire on September 24. 

A local forest Type 4 team is currently in command of the Dillon Fire.
properties.title: Dillon Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The fires, which started on the afternoon of Aug 25, 2025, are burning in steep, rugged, and remote terrain and is moving north toward Granite Peak. Most of the fire footprint is currently within the Trinity Alps Wilderness.
properties.field_incident_overview: The command of Swift Complex is being transferred to Shasta-Trinity National Forest on September 10, 2025. The command of the Lick Fire was transferred to the Forest Service on September 7, 2025, at 7 AM. The Peak Fire is west of Lake Trinity and east of Mule Creek, while the Lick Fire is in Poison Canyon, southeast of the Carrville community.
properties.title: Swift Complex

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Martin Fire was sparked from one of more than 320 strikes from a dry lightning storm that passed over the area on the evening of August 26, 2025.

There are no additional updates planned for this fire.
properties.title: Martin

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Crown Creek Fire began on August 29, 2025, following lightning strikes in Stevens County, northeastern Washington. Burning through a mix of grass, brush, and timber in rugged terrain, the fire grew quickly, forcing multiple evacuation levels for nearby communities. By early September, the fire had expanded to several thousand acres, threatening homes, powerlines, property, and livestock. State mobilization was authorized on August 31, bringing in additional resources and strike teams to support local districts/agencies actively involved in initial attack suppression efforts.

At its peak, the fire reached over 14,000 acres. Thanks to favorable weather, aggressive firefighting efforts, and coordination with cooperators, containment steadily increased to more than 90 percent by the end of September. While mop-up, hazard tree removal, and suppression repair continue, officials remain alert to interior hotspots and lingering smoke impacts. The Crown Creek Fire has underscored both the challenges of rapid fire growth in mixed fuels and the importance of strong interagency coordination in protecting local communities. Over the duration of the fire, multiple incident management teams worked toward containment of the fire and implement suppression repair.

Evacuations: All evacuations were lifted on Sept 23, 2025. Stevens County Interactive Evacuation Map is available and allows users to enter their address to identify if they may be impacted by an incident. Information may also be provided on the Stevens County Emergency Management Facebook page as needed.

Emergency Notifications: It is recommend that all residents in the area sign up for emergency notifications through Hyper-Reach for when a future incident occurs. Hyper-reach is Stevens County’s emergency alert system. It provides rapid notification of hazardous and urgent situations through the use of phone calls, texting and email messages. TTY/TDD service is also available for the hearing impaired.
properties.title: Crown Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Wildcat Fire was started by lightning in the William O. Douglas Wilderness and was first reported on Monday, August 25, 2025. It grew slowly until Saturday, August 30, when winds caused increased fire activity, with the fire spotting and flanking. Firefighters were challenged with hot and dry conditions, which fueled fire growth. Complex Incident Management NW Team 10 assumed command of the fire on September 3, 2025. On September 16, 2025, the fire was returned to a Type 3 IMT team. The SEWAIMT Team 1 took command of the fire at 0600 on Tuesday, Sep 16, 2025. On September 29, 2025 command of the Wildcat Fire was transferred to a local Type 3 Team.  

On October 8, 2025 command of the Wildcat Fire was transferred to the local unit. There will not be additional updates on this fire.

For updated closure information, please visit https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/okanogan-wenatchee/alerts.
properties.title: Wildcat Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Katy Creek Fire started on August 30, 2025, following lightning strikes in the Colville National Forest, northwest of Kettle Falls, Washington. Burning in steep, rocky terrain with heavy timber, the fire posed challenges for direct suppression and required extensive use of hand crews and aerial resources. Early growth reached several hundred acres within days, ultimately expanding to nearly 4,700 acres. The fire threatened nearby structures and prompted road closures and area restrictions to protect public safety. Fire behavior ranged from smoldering and creeping to isolated torching and spotting under dry, windy conditions. Containment steadily increased as crews conducted mop-up, firing operations, and hazard tree mitigation, with the fire reported at over 90 percent contained in late September. Managed in coordination with other regional incidents, the Katy Creek Fire highlighted both the difficulty of firefighting in rugged forest terrain and the effectiveness of coordinated interagency response.

Closures: Colville National Forest initially implemented a closure order for the Katy Creek Fire but reduced the size on Sept 23, 2025.  View the entire order and map on their website.

Evacuations: Ferry County Sheriff's Office lifted all evacuations on Sept 26, 2025. You can get futures alerts about emergencies and other important community news by signing up for the Ferry County Alert System. You will receive time-sensitive messages wherever you specify, such as your home, mobile, or business phones, email address, text messages, and more.
properties.title: Katy Creek

properties.field_incident_overview: The Root Fire was discovered September 1, 2025 north of Castle Creek and west of Castella.  Law enforcement officers from the Forest Service have determined that the Root Fire was caused by an escaped campfire. The fire is burning in Timber understory and grass in steep terrain. Firefighters are working to keep the fire north of Forest Road 39N25; South of the Castle Crags Wilderness; East of Whalen Summit and West of the North Fork of Castle Creek. The fire is burning in steep, rugged terrain with seasonally dry and receptive fuel.
properties.title: Root Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: Tacoma Creek Fire has been returned to the local district for management activities.  This page will no longer be updated.  For current information, please contact NEWICC at 509-685-6900.
properties.title: Tacoma Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Lower Sugarloaf Fire was a lightning-caused fire located near Sugarloaf Lookout that began on September 1, 2025. The fire burned partially in the footprint of the 1994 Tyee Fire and the 2018 Cougar Creek Fire, as well as thick timber and brush that has not seen fire since records began being kept.  

Management of the fire was transferred back to the local units at 6:00 pm on October 23, 2025.

For future updates on the fire or related forest closure, please visit: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/okanogan-wenatchee/alerts
properties.title: Lower Sugarloaf Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Labor Mountain Fire was started by lightning on Monday, September 1st, due to a dry lightning storm passing over Central Washington that started multiple new wildfires in the Chelan County and Kittitas County areas of the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest. It started in steep terrain between Standup and Stafford Creeks, about 10 miles northeast of Cle Elum, WA. This is one of the drier areas of the Cle Elum Ranger District. With the many fires started in the region from this storm, firefighting resources were stretched. An aggressive, full-suppression strategy has been implemented, while protecting critical resources at risk. These resources include local communities, Highway 97 and other infrastructure, historic structures, recreation residences and popular recreation areas. Public and fire fighter safety is the top priority.

Management of the fire is being transferred back to the local units of the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest, Bureau of Land Management, and Washington Department of Natural Resources at 6:00 pm on October 23.

For future updates related to the fire and forest closure, please visit the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest website:  https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/okanogan-wenatchee/alerts
properties.title: Labor Mountain Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: The Cedar Fire is being managed by California Interagency Incident Management Team 2 until Tuesday, September 9 at 0700.
properties.title: Cedar Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: On September 1, 2025, Snow Peak fire was reported in Ferry County, 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is located in a remote area approximately 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is burning in an inventoried roadless area with very difficult access by foot. Resources responding include crews, air attack, and helicopters. The Snow Peak cabin, a valuable recreation site in the alpine area NW of the fire, has been prepped with structure wrap and there have been past fuel treatments in the immediate vicinity of the cabin which significantly lowers the risk of impact.
properties.title: Snow Peak

properties.field_incident_description: Lightning-caused wildfire north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex.
properties.field_incident_overview:
On August 27, following storms across the area, a lightning-caused fire was reported north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex. 

Area, trail, and camp closures: Visitors should check the park Fire Closures page prior to a visit for up-to-date trail and camp closure information. Closures are in place to protect the public.
properties.title: Perry Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Marks Creek Fire was reported just after noon on September 2nd, burning in timber and brush approximately 18 miles east of Prineville, Oregon on Ochoco National Forest lands. Aggressive initial attack included engines, dozers, single engine super scoopers, helicopters, large air tankers, and other air and ground resources.

The Central Oregon Fire Management Service (COFMS) Type 3 Incident Management Team, Incident Commander Fore, assumed command of the fire the morning of September 3rd.  Operations focused on establishing and strengthening control lines. 

COFMS Type 3 Team transitioned command of the Marks Creek Fire to Oregon Department of Forestry's Complex Incident Management Team 2, Incident Commander Matt Howard at 6:00 p.m. on September 4th. Crews continue to focus operations on reinforcing containment lines, patrolling the perimeter for spot fires and slop overs, and working to construct fireline to limit fire growth.

ODF CIMT 2 transitioned command of the fire to the Prairie Division Type 4 organization from the Ochoco National Forest at 7:00 a.m. on September 12th. Crews will continue to work on suppression repair around the perimeter of the fire.
properties.title: Marks Creek

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Bridge Fire was reported on 9/3/2025 at 10:29 pm on the Malheur National Forest, within the Blue Mountain Ranger District. The fire is located approximately 9.9 miles northeast of Prairie City, near Dixie Lookout.

Fire crews are actively engaged in suppression efforts, with additional resources enroute to assist. The fire is burning in timber and brush within a steep, and roadless area. The cause of the fire is undetermined at this time. Due to the steep, rugged terrain in which the fire is located and the large amount of heavy, down and dead fuels present, the fire will remain on the landscape until a season ending event such as heavy rain or snow. Firefighters will work to limit the spread of the fire and protect values at risk while accounting for public and firefighter safety.

Motorists traveling along Highway 26 could see increased traffic and visible smoke, as firefighting operations continue.

For all evacuation information please go to:
Genasys Evacuation Map - https://protect.genasys.com/hazards/2001c3ee-af7d-4aa9-827a-232b150669fd?z=10.000105433629999&latlon=44.62346226723207%2C-118.62319026453702

For Closure information please go to:
Malheur National Forest | Bridge Fire Area Closure | Forest Service - https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/malheur/newsroom/releases/bridge-fire-area-closure-updated
properties.title: Bridge Fire - OR

properties.field_incident_description: Wildland Fire
properties.field_incident_overview:
Evacuations: Curry County Sheriff John Ward has removed all evacation levels for the Moon Complex. 

There is no camping, hiking or fishing from the bank on the Rogue River between Marial and Foster Bar. 

Bear Camp Road remains closed due to extreme hazards.

On September 3, a lightning event on the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest caused a number of fires in the vicinity of the Rogue River about 11 miles northeast of Agness, Oregon. Six of these made up the initial Moon Complex: the Backbone, Brushy, Pinnacle, Tate, Paradise, and Stair fires. As of September 8, Paradise, Stair, and Brushy fires burned into the perimeters of other fires. Tate Fire is fully contained at 26 acres. Suppression and repair work continue on the Backbone and Pinnacle fires. 

Fire Restrictions: Tuesday, October 16, 2025, The Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest decreased the Fire Danger Rating to LOW across all five Ranger Districts and removed Public Use Restrictions forest-wide as well as on the Wild & Scenic section of the Rogue River. Industrial Fire Precaution Level (IFPL) 1 remains in place.  To learn more, visit the forest website: https://www.fs.usda.gov/alerts/rogue-siskiyou/alerts-notices

Fire Repair: There has been no measurable growth on the fire for a while. Repair of fire line and roadways is the primary focus of resources engaged on the Moon Complex

Road Closures: Key travel routes to the public, including the FS Road 33 between Agness and Powers, OR, and the FS Road 2308 also known as Burnt Ridge Road between Merlin and Agness, OR, and the FS 3348 Road also known as the Eden Valley Road continue to support fire suppression and repair activities. Bear Camp Road remains closed for hazard treatments.

Wild and Scenic Rogue River: Camping is not allowed at this time along the wild and scenic portion of the river. Please refer to Facebook page for the locations of rest break areas.
properties.title: Moon Complex

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Kelsey Peak Fire is located 15 miles west of Glendale in the Lower Rogue River Corridor on Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Medford District administered lands. The Kelsey Peak Fire, along with numerous other fires, was sparked by passing thunderstorms on September 3, 2025. Initial attack by Oregon Department of Forestry’s (ODF) Southwest Oregon District was immediate. Despite aggressive firefighting tactics by local agencies over the next several days, the fire continued to grow.

Extended attack on the fire continued to challenge firefighters in steep, rugged terrain with persistent smoke halting air operations. ODF Complex Incident Management Team 1, Incident Commander Dan Quinones, was ordered on September 6 to manage suppression efforts on the Kelsey Peak Fire. Team 1 was in-briefed by ODF and BLM on Sunday, September 7, with transfer of command at 6:00 a.m. Monday, September 8.
properties.title: Kelsey Peak Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.
properties.field_incident_overview: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.
properties.title: Black Rock Fire

properties.field_incident_description:
The fires occurred in steep terrain with heavy fuel loading with little to no road access. Suppression tactics were based on several safety concerns, including a lack of ingress and egress options that would result in unacceptable medevac times. Decisions are heavily based on firefighter safety and resources at risk. Resources continue to assess for opportunities for direct and indirect options.
A Type 5 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. Smoke from the fires are visible along the Hwy 56 corridor.

A closure order is in effect for roads and trails in the vicinity of the fires.
properties.field_incident_overview:
On August 31st, a lightning storm ignited 31 fires across the Kootenai National Forest.  Firefighting resources, (engines and hand crew modules) responded to these fires throughout the evening of Aug 31st and in the morning on September 1st. 10 lightning fires were ignited on the Cabinet Ranger District including the Isabella, Moran, and Lost Girl Fires which started in the Cabinet Mountain Wilderness.  Kootenai Rappelers were inserted into the Lost Girl fire on the evening of the August 31st.  Active fire behavior combined with difficult access and extremely steep and cliffy terrain compromised the safety of firefighters during this initial suppression efforts and firefighters disengaged ground operation.  A Type 5 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. 

Isabella: Start Date: 09/01/2025; Size: 1,411 acres as of September 28, 2025

Lost Girl: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: 309acres as of September 28, 2025

Moran Fire: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: .2 acres as of September 6, 2025 -The fire has not shown any smoke or heat for several days

*Updates will be made with any significant changes in fire behavior or growth. Updates may not occur daily.
properties.field_title_and_unit: MTKNF Isabella and Lost Girl Fires
properties.title: Isabella and Lost Girl Fires

properties.field_incident_description:
The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge.
October 6, 2025: All future updates will be posted on the Foley Ridge Facebook Page.
https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=61580297113240
properties.field_incident_overview:
The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge. 

October 6, 2025: All future updates will be posted on the Foley Ridge Facebook Page. 
https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=61580297113240
properties.title: Foley Ridge Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
On September 6, 2025, USFS fire managers were able to assess a new fire start caused by lightning, named the Tunnel Creek Fire, located in a remote area of the Buckhorn Wilderness in Olympic National Forest.

The fire is roughly 10 miles west of Quilcene, Washington and 1.5 miles west of the Tunnel Creek Trailhead accessed from FS Road 2740.

Updates related to the Tunnel Creek Fire will be shared on the Bear Gulch Fire Inciweb page as they are being managed by the same team.
properties.title: Tunnel Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The wildfire is located within the Chiricahua Wilderness, Douglas Ranger District. It is not threatening any structures at this time.
properties.field_incident_overview:
The fire area is characterized by substantial accumulations of snags and dead-and-down fuels—legacy
debris from the 2011 Horseshoe 2 fire. While these heavy fuels are present in abundance, they are not
currently driving fire behavior in a significant way. Instead, active burning is concentrated within the
needle cast layered throughout timber stringers, where fine fuels are promoting persistent surface fire
activity. Ground operations are further complicated by overgrown trails and thick vegetation, which
restrict access and reduce maneuverability for suppression crews. These conditions, combined with
elevated fuel loading and obstructed containment corridors, continue to pose considerable challenges to
control efforts and require adaptive strategies to improve containment success.
properties.title: Stanford Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Status: On Wednesday, November 5, 2025, a private landowner detected smoke south of Circleville, WV in Pendleton County. Pendleton County emergency personnel immediately contacted the USDA Forest Service who responded. This wildfire is being managed under unified command with the State of West Virginia and the USDA Forest Service, Monongahela National Forest.  Initial acreage was estimated at 50 acres, with active, wind driven fire. The fire is burning in an oak-hickory forest type, with very steep, mountainous terrain making ground access difficult. Safety of firefighters and the public are the top priorities.  

Planned Operations: Firefighters will continue to build and reinforce containment lines around the perimeter of the fire. Ground operations are supported by engines and hand crews. A Type-2 helicopter has been ordered and is scheduled to arrive later today.
properties.title: Woodside Fire
